channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Nashville, Rolling Parties Rage at Every Stoplight
item.description: As Nashville’s popularity has grown, so has the “transportainment” business — a motley assortment including old buses, farm tractors and a truck with a hot tub. Many think it has gotten out of hand.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and William DeShazer
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times.
item.media:description: The Big Green Tractor Tours trailer rolled through downtown Nashville in August.

item.title: Alabama Begins Removing Racist Language From Its Constitution
item.description: Many outdated provisions have long since been invalidated, but the language that was specifically intended to enshrine white supremacy has remained.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: Andi Rice for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re having real-deal conversations where people may not have been having those conversations before, conversations we should have had a long time ago,” State Rep. Merika Coleman said.

item.title: The ‘Murdaugh Murders’ in South Carolina: What to Know
item.description: The unsolved killings of a lawyer’s wife and son have brought new scrutiny to three other deaths in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Mic Smith/Associated Press
item.media:description: Alex Murdaugh at his bond hearing on Thursday in Varnville, S.C., after surrendering to face insurance fraud and other charges.

item.title: Harassed and Harangued, Poll Workers Now Have a New Form of Defense
item.description: Threatened by extremists and under fire by politicians, election workers now have their own legal defense network. It’s a perk they never expected to need.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling site in El Centro, Calif., during this month’s recall vote for governor.

item.title: Abortion Lawsuits Target Texas Doctor Who Said He Violated Law
item.description: The suits, brought by men in Arkansas and Illinois, appear to be the first under a state law that bans most abortions after the six-week mark.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The abortion rights group Reproaction outside the U.S. Supreme Court this month.

item.title: C.D.C. Mandates Measles Vaccinations, Quarantines for Afghan Refugees
item.description: Officials know of 16 confirmed cases of measles among Afghan evacuees and Americans who fled Afghanistan in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of Afghans and foreigners passed through checkpoints at the Kabul airport last month.

item.title: After Setback, Democrats Vow to Push Ahead on Immigration Overhaul
item.description: After a top Senate official rejected a proposal to legalize millions of undocumented immigrants, Democrats said they would craft an alternative.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Eileen Sullivan
item.category: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats had been seeking to use the far-reaching domestic policy package to grant legal status to Dreamers, immigrants who were granted Temporary Protected Status for humanitarian reasons, close to one million farmworkers and millions more who are deemed “essential workers.”

item.title: D.C. mayor says adults in schools and eligible student-athletes must get vaccinated by Nov. 1.
item.description: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser’s announcement eliminates an earlier testing option for school employees but retains exemptions for religious or health reasons.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press
item.media:description: All adults and many eligible students will soon need to be vaccinated in Washington, D.C., schools.

item.title: Progressives Worry Their Priorities Will Be Left Behind, Despite Biden’s Bold Words
item.description: The White House says it is committed to reducing gun violence, keeping abortion safe and legal, and protecting voting rights. But that has done little to ease anxiety among activists.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voting rights rally in Washington last month. Privately, White House officials have been trying to assure activists that they plan to turn their attention to the issue after their push on infrastructure.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Pfizer’s pediatric vaccine
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Biden to Raise the Cap on Refugees to 125,000
item.description: The move indicates the president’s intention to open the country’s doors after four years in which the Trump administration sought to prevent refugees from settling in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Alaa Al Sukhni/Reuters
item.media:description: Asmaa Rasheed, a Syrian refugee storyteller living in Zaatari refugee camp, in the Jordanian city of Mafraq, near the border with Syria, in June.

item.title: Kenneth Schoen, ‘Linchpin’ in Criminal Justice Reform, Dies at 89
item.description: In Minnesota, New York and nationally, he pushed for better conditions for prison inmates and more options for “community-based corrections.”
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: ‘America’s Oldest Park Ranger’ Is Only Her Latest Chapter
item.description: Betty Reid Soskin has fought to ensure that American history includes the stories that get overlooked. As she turns 100, few stories have been more remarkable than hers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Chanell Stone for The New York Times

item.title: Parents May Hesitate to Vaccinate Younger Children Against Covid
item.description: Children have so far been vaccinated at lower rates than adults, and polling indicates greater hesitation among parents of younger children.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damarcus Crimes, 13, receiving a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine while his mother, Christina, and brother, Deshaun, 13, look on in San Antonio, Texas, in May.

item.title: Mnuchin’s Private Equity Fund Raises $2.5 Billion
item.description: The former Treasury secretary has attracted investment from Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fund was started this year by Steven Mnuchin, who was President Donald J. Trump’s Treasury secretary, and is focused on technology and financial services investments.

item.title: U.S. to Lift Travel Ban for Vaccinated Visitors
item.description: Travelers who provide proof of full vaccination against the coronavirus before boarding a flight will be able to enter the United States.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Mark Landler and Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Justin Lane/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The halt to the 18-month ban on travel from 33 countries includes members of the European Union, China, Iran, South Africa, Brazil and India.

item.title: Abortion Poll: Most Americans Disagree With Supreme Court on Texas Ban
item.description: Monmouth University Poll released its findings the same day the Supreme Court added hearings on a Mississippi abortion case.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators rallying for abortion rights outside the Supreme Court in Washington this month.

item.title: Wisconsin Republican Defends Legitimacy of 2020 Election Investigation
item.description: Michael Gableman, a conservative former State Supreme Court Justice, declared that the state’s partisan inquiry into the election results was not meant to overturn President Biden’s victory.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jessica Reilly/Telegraph Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael Gableman, right, in 2015, during his tenure as a State Supreme Court justice in Wisconsin.

item.title: California's New Housing Laws: Here's What to Know
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom has signed two bills aimed at easing the state’s housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes and homes under construction in Antioch, Calif., last year.

item.title: Democrats Turn to Fiscal Matters and Raising Debt Limit
item.description: The approach essentially dares Republicans to follow through on their threats to oppose raising the debt limit, by coupling it with urgently needed federal spending.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi at the Capitol earlier this month.

item.title: Medicare Expansion Clashes With Health Care for the Poor as Budget Bill Shrinks
item.description: Under pressure to cut the bill’s cost, Democrats disagree over whether to offer more benefits to older Americans or to cover more of the working poor.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: House Committee on Ways and Means
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Some mobile clinics, like this one in Knoxville, Tenn., provide free medical, health and dental care to residents in states where the governor has not expanded Medicaid.

item.title: Biden Pushes Global Plan to Battle Covid-19 as National Gaps Widen
item.description: The U.N.-backed vaccine program is so far behind schedule that not even 10 percent of the population in poor countries is fully vaccinated, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Mahesh Kumar A/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Serum Institute of India reneged on exporting hundreds of millions of Covid vaccine doses designated for poor countries in order to focus on domestic distribution.

item.title: At the Supreme Court, a Plea to Reveal Secret Surveillance Rulings
item.description: The justices will soon consider whether to hear a case arguing that the First Amendment requires disclosure of a secret court’s major rulings.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court building in January.

item.title: U.S. Troops Still Deploying to Iraq, Even as Afghan War Ends
item.description: In the other country the United States invaded after 9/11, American troops continue to serve combat tours in harm’s way. Meet the soldiers headed for duty in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The First Stryker Brigade Combat Team, Fourth Infantry Division, is deploying to Iraq for a nine-month tour of duty. A bus carried soldiers of the brigade, based at Fort Carson, Colo., to board a military flight on Sept. 12.

item.title: Residents of Del Rio Feel the Impact of the Migrant Crisis
item.description: The influx of thousands of migrants has led to squalor under a bridge, and a dispirited town beyond it.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval and James Dobbins
item.category: Laughlin Air Force Base (Del Rio, Tex)
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants walk across the Rio Grande River carrying food and other supplies back to their encampment.

item.title: What We Know About Brian Laundrie, the Fiancé of Gabby Petito
item.description: Mr. Laundrie, who is missing, was the last known person to have been with Ms. Petito before she went missing, according to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Moab City Police Department/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: A still image from police body camera footage recorded on Aug. 12, released by the Moab City Police Department in Utah, shows Brian Laundrie speaking with police when they responded to an altercation between Mr. Laundrie and his fiancée, Gabrielle Petito.

item.title: Who is Gabby Petito?
item.description: Gabrielle Petito had worked as a pharmacy technician to save money for a crosscountry trip with her boyfriend.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Hauser, Maria Cramer and Michael Levenson

item.title: Democrats Dealt a Blow on Immigration Plans
item.description: The Senate’s parliamentarian ruled that Democrats’ plan to give 8 million immigrants a path to citizenship could not be achieved through the reconciliation process.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)
item.media:credit: Shawn Thew/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Members of United We Dream rallied near the White House in August to demand Congress deliver citizenship for millions of immigrants this year.

item.title: Remains Matching Description of Gabrielle Petito Were Found in Wyoming Camping Area
item.description: Ms. Petito was last known to be driving toward the area with her fiancé as they embarked on a cross-country trip, according to her family.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Amber Baesler/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Teton County Search and Rescue vehicle drives in the Spread Creek area in the Bridger-Teton National Forest, just east of Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. Authorities say they have found a body believed to be Gabrielle Petito, who went missing on a trip with her boyfriend.
